channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: The Rate Cut Happened. Not All Borrowing Costs Are Going Down.
item.description: U.S. Treasury yields rose after the Fed cut short-term rates.

item.title: After Fed’s 50-basis-point rate cut, where should I invest $50,000? I’m 38 — and have a high risk tolerance.
item.description: The U.S. Federal Reserve made its biggest cut to the benchmark rate in 16 years on Wednesday.

item.title: The Fed Is Flying Blind. Investors Don't Seem to Care.
item.description: Markets embraced the central bank’s spirit of dovishness following the big rate cut this past week.

item.title: Apple iPhone 16 is now on sale, and T-Mobile’s CEO says it’s selling better than last year’s
item.description: T-Mobile Chief Executive Mike Sievert says it’s “nonsense” that the iPhone 16 line’s preorder sales are underwhelming.

item.title: Here's What It's Like to Retire in Rural America
item.description: Seven retirees open up about their finances and how they spend their time in the country.

item.title: No. 1 NFL pick Caleb Williams asked for his $40 million contract to go into an LLC. Can he do that?
item.description: There are financial benefits to treating yourself as a brand instead of an employee.

item.title: Sorry, the Fed Can't Save Us From a Bear Market
item.description: If stocks already were due for a tumble and the economy for a recession, the Fed’s rate cut probably didn’t avert it.

item.title: How low could mortgage rates go now that the Fed has finally started cutting? Economists weigh in.
item.description: Here’s what the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cut means for mortgage rates.

item.title: The Score: Intuitive Machines, Intel, Nike and More Stocks That Defined the Week
item.description: Here are some of the major companies whose stocks moved on the week’s news.

item.title: Shohei Ohtani’s 50th-home-run ball could be worth $500,000 to the fan who caught it
item.description: Aaron Judge’s 62nd home-run ball in 2022 sold for $1.5 million at auction
